physDesc.p: M53. Anon. Typescript fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. With the author's ms corrections. 26p. Paginated 1-25. Two pages paginated 22.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Anon.

For many centuries
aft after Britain became an island
the historian says, the untamed forest was king.
On the matted boughs of that forest innumerable birds sang;
but their song was only heard by a few skin clad hunters
in the clearings. Did the desire to sing come to one
of those savages because he heard the birds sing? & didDid he
rest his stone axe against a tree for a moment> The tree

was felled; some sort of hut
ws was made from its branches, and
then by degrees, the clearing became larger; the birds
fewer; and the human voice sung instead. & The first songs
are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs; winter

songs. & for there was no comfort
indoor indoors , little
light and no books.
The eye therefore was xxxx more active in the first sxxxxxxx

singers than in ourselves. And some parts of
Englab England
can still be seen as they saw it. Now and then by choosing

a view carefully to shut out a chimney or a
bungalwo bungalow ,
we can still see a flat fen, reed whispering, waterlogged;
or a down, covered w still with turf only And over??? on the
down lies a green scar, along which the travellers came,
with the pack horses, dressed in wool, not in skins,
History of England by G. M. Trevelyan p. 3
